sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) f 20
div.ab: Dugdale summarizes this entry: see Appendix 11. Apparently Lincoln’s Inn had earlier observed or tolerated revels on many holidays, including the feasts of Saints William, Hugh, Edmund, Peter, and Thomas. These multiple holidays were now rationalized down to four, including two which persisted well into the seventeenth century: All Hallows (1 November) and the Purification of the Virgin or Candlemas (2 February). This entry is referenced by a table-of-contents type notation on f 11, annotated ‘4 Reuells fo: 20.a’ with the following summary:

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) f 62v
div.ab: The ‘skafoldys in Smythfeld’ were apparently for jousts or tournaments at the coronation of Queen Margaret: see John Stow, The Annales of England (London, 1592; STC : 23334), 623 – 4. This is the earliest of nine such references to jousts or tournaments: see also 1466–7 (also mentioned 1467–8), 1477–8, 1494–5, 1501–2, 1510–11 (twice), 1532–3, 1546–7, and 1565–6.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 87
div.ab: Sir John Talbot (1413–60) succeeded as fifth earl of Shrewsbury in 1453 (l.7). See REED’s Patrons and Performances Web Site for more information.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) f 100
div.ab: The list of elected officers for 35 Henry VI is also entered on f 12v of the next volume in the series, including 'Hundysfeld Mayster de les Revelles.'

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) f 125v
div.ab: The list is also entered but cancelled on f 123v, where it carries the equivalent title in Latin: 'Magister Revellorum.'

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) f 149
div.ab: Antoine, count of La Roche (‘Bastardum filium ducis Burgundie,’ p 11, l.2), came to England in 1467 to arrange a marriage between his brother, Charles, count of Charolais, and Lady Margaret, sister of Edward IV. The joust, which took place in June, is described in John Stow, The Annales of England (London, 1592; STC : 23334), 689 – 90. Anthony Wydevill, Lord Scales, was the victor. On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a1 (Black Book 1) ff 152v, 153
div.ab: The ‘Skaffeldes’ referred to in these entries were used at the tournament held in Smithfield during Trinity term of the previous accounting year (see pp 10–11).

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 88
div.ab: This entry is immediately followed by the statement, ‘The daie fell oute to be ffridaie,’ perhaps referring to All Hallows, which in 1471 fell on a Friday. If reference is rather to Christmas, the implied year would be 1472. As the original of this antiquarian document remains lost, the year must be regarded as conjectural.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 88
div.ab: The account is headed ‘Christmas Daie Anno 13o Edwardi 4. Dies Dominica,’ but in 1473 Christmas fell on a Saturday. Christmas fell on a Sunday in 1474. As the original of this antiquarian document remains lost, the year must be regarded as conjectural.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 88v
div.ab: The occurrence of two different terms for harper raises the question of whether these musicians might have been playing different kinds of string instruments. Although ‘fidicen’ can refer in Anglo-Latin to a fiddler, here the performer is firmly identified in English as a harper. Despite the development in fifteenth-century Italy of the cithern, an instrument to which vocabulary derived from the Latin ‘cithera’ was applied, there is no corresponding evidence that ‘citherator’ was used in Anglo-Latin to refer to players on other plucked string instruments, and 1476–7 would be quite early for the cithern and its vocabulary to have spread to England. The two remaining possibilities would appear to be either that the accountant was simply employing synonyms for variety or that players on two different types or shapes of harp are being distinguished. See ‘cittern’ in L. Macy (ed), Grove Music Online.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 1) f 32
div.ab: In June 1477 Edward IV ordered an unusually elaborate London midsummer watch to entertain ambassadors from France and from Scotland: see Anne Lancashire, London Civic Theatre: City Drama and Pageantry from Roman Times to 1558 (Cambridge, 2002), 155–6. On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 88v
div.ab: For the ‘Ductori de le Marmosett & Iennet,’ see pp 918–19, endnote to MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90v.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 89
div.ab: For the keeper of the baboon, see pp 918–19, endnote to MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 2) f 10v
div.ab: The list is also entered on f 7 but cancelled.

div.head: LI Lib: MS Misc. 2 ff ii-ii verso
div.ab: This note occurs on the second flyleaf, with no obvious connection to the statutes which constitute the principal subject of the manuscript. It seems probable but not absolutely certain that the Inner Temple disguising was repeated on 30 January. Noblemen named here are John de Vere, thirteenth earl of Oxford; Thomas Stanley, tenth earl of Derby; George Talbot, seventh earl of Shrewsbury; Edward, second Baron Hastings; and Sir William Stanley, lord chamberlain.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 2) f 13
div.ab: The list is cancelled with crossing vertical lines; major offices are re-entered on f 14.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 2) f 17v
div.ab: The list is also entered on f 17 but cancelled. An undated list of the same minor officers is also entered on f 14v, and also cancelled.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 89
div.ab: Earlier on f 89 occurs an entry for 1490–1 (‘Christmas Anno 6 Henrici 7’): ‘Commons brake vpp nere Christmas Daie, and the Company became wholie dispersed by reason of wynter Sicknes then.’

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 2) ff 33, 33v
div.ab:
The editors have not succeeded in identifying the occasion of this joust. On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.
The warden of the Fleet Prison in 1490–1 was Richard Babyngton (TNA: PRO E 101/516/21); in 1498, William Babyngton (TNA: PRO Cal. Inq. p.m., xii, no. 28). The warden in 1594–5 was probably one of these two men. The editors are grateful to Christine Winter for supplying this information.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90v
div.ab:
In the Tudor and earlier periods, performing exotic animals (excluding bears) appear to have been patronized exclusively by royalty, particularly the monarch. This is borne out by a search of patronized performing animal troupes in REED’s Patrons and Performances Web Site. It is therefore probable that the leader of the marmoset and jennet (a small Spanish horse) who is paid at Furnival’s Inn in Christmas 1481–2 (p 17, ll.25–6) was patronized by Edward IV, and the keeper of the baboon (p 19, l.5) who is paid at the same Inn on Christmas Day 1485 was patronized by Henry VII (his newborn son, Arthur, prince of Wales, later patronized a baboon keeper who appears in New Romney, Kent, in 1494–5: see REED: Kent: Diocese of Canterbury, vol 2, p 753). It is probable the mention of ‘Lyons’ here (l.16) and the payments to ‘Pescod the keeper of the Lyons’ in 1497–8 (p 25, l.6) and to ‘Pescodde’ in 1498–9 (p 25, l.19) are all references to the king’s lion keeper. Henry VII’s lion keeper was paid at Shrewsbury in April 1493; his predecessors, Edward IV and Richard III, also kept lions that travelled outside of London.
Pescod seems to have been the keeper of at least one other kind of exotic animal, as attested by two entries from the Magdalen College Libri Computi not included in REED: Oxford. In 1494–5 (f 26), ‘Solutum Pescode seruanti quandam bestiam vocatam ly Mermusytt ex consilio seniorum quia rex erat apud Woodstocke xij d.’ (‘12d paid to Pescod, keeping a beast called the marmoset, by the council of the seniors because the king was at Woodstock’). In 1495–6 (f 40), ‘Solutum pescod ducenti duo animalia nuncupata Mermosettes in regardo viij d.’ (‘8d paid in reward to Pescod, leading two animals called marmosets’). That Henry VII kept marmosets is indicated by a payment to the king’s marmoset in Dover, Kent, in 1488–9: see REED: Kent: Diocese of Canterbury, vol 2, p 374. (Thanks to Mark Sorrell for drawing attention to the Magdalen College entries and for sharing his knowledge concerning patronage of exotic animals in early modern England.)

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book 2, Part 2) ff 34, 35
div.ab: The list of appointments to Christmas offices and accompanying memoranda are also entered but cancelled (with crossing vertical lines) on f 32v.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90
div.ab: For ‘Pescod the keeper of the Lyons,’ see pp 918–19, endnote to MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a2 (Black Book, Part 2) f 50
div.ab: For ‘Pescodde,’ see pp 918–19, endnote to MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 90v.

div.head: BL: Hargrave MS 388 ff 122-2v
div.ab: J.H. Baker (ed), The Reports of Sir John Spelman, vol 1, Selden Society 93 (London, 1977), ix, notes that Sir John Spelman’s report about the Christmas revels held in Gray’s Inn ‘“in ancient temps” almost certainly belongs to his student days, and is the earliest detailed description of those curious rites.’ As Spelman entered Gray’s Inn about 1500 and as the composition date of his ‘Reports’ is unknown, we have assigned this report to c 1500. Of the vocal pieces mentioned in Spelman’s report, ‘what shall we singe in worshipe of this daie’ (p 27, ll.7–8), ‘ther shall none reigne downe reigne’ (p 27, ll.9–10), and ‘rounde abowt the fier’ (p 27, l.10) remain unidentified; ‘nescienz mater’ (p 27, l.2) is the motet ‘Nesciens mater virgo virum’ by Jean Mouton (1459–1522). Baker, Reports, vol 1, p 234, identifies ‘fare well et have good daye’ (p 27, l.18) with an Epiphany carol found in Balliol College: MS 354 and printed in A.W. Pollard, Fifteenth Century Prose and Verse (Westminster, 1903), 89 – 90, as well as in Edith Rickert, Ancient English Christmas Carols (London and New York, 1914), 225–6, and Richard Leighton Greene (ed), The Early English Christmas Carols, 2nd ed (Oxford, 1977), 85.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 91v
div.ab: The ‘Iustes & Turnamentes’ were held in connection with negotiations for the marriage of Margaret Tudor to James IV of Scotland, which were concluded 25 January 1501/2: see John Stow, The Annales of England (London, 1592; STC : 23334), 807. (The wedding did not take place until 15 January 1502/3). On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: MT Lib: LOFT MS 97 f 91v
div.ab: Bland, in ‘Fifteenth-Century Revels,’ p 265, n 1, identifies the ‘Ladie Princes’ as Margaret, daughter of Henry VII. This is improbable: Margaret was married by proxy 15 January 1502/3 to James IV of Scotland, leaving for Edinburgh on 8 July 1503. She was formally married in Scotland on 8 August 1503. By Christmas 1503–4, therefore, she was the queen of Scotland and no longer a member of the English court. The princess being referred to here is Katherine of Arragon, dowager princess of Wales, who had been betrothed to Prince Henry on 25 June 1503. Unlike Margaret, Katherine (as princess) is known to have patronized performers between 1500–2 and in 1507. See REED’s Patrons and Performances Web Site for more information.

div.head: MT Arch: MT.1/MPA/No. 1 f 8
div.ab: The date of this parliament is given as ‘die lune in commemoracione animarum’ (f 7v); however, All Souls fell on a Sunday in 1505 and it seems more probable that the parliament was held on the Monday.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 ff 18, 19
div.ab: Folios damaged by post–World War II fire; the dates are supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) ff 24v, 25, 25v
div.ab: On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 22
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 25v
div.ab: The names of the four masters of the revels are entered again at the foot of f 26: ‘lacton, Godolphyn, Lambourn,’ and ‘E Gyfford.’

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 38
div.ab:
On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.
A previous entry on this folio, also in the account of the treasurer’s receipts, records Thomas More’s payment of a fine of £5 for exemption from the offices of Christmas marshal and keeper of the Black Book.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 28
div.ab: The names of the four masters of the revels are repeated on f 28v.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 30
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 33
div.ab: Earlier on the same folio occurs an entry under 1 November listing as masters of the revels only ‘Verney,’ ‘Rede,’ and ‘B (blank).’

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 34v
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 38
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; Symondson (see the footnoted reading supplied from Inderwick) is not among the masters of the revels listed on f 36v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) ff 71, 76, 79
div.ab: Lobbe, the fool (‘lobbe le ffolet,’ l.9; ‘lobbe,’ ll.13, 29; ‘fatuo,’ l.34), not encountered by any previous REED editor, may have been mistreated in the course of his activities, and was thus not only paid for his efforts but compensated for a wound and various losses.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 42v
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 46v
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 ff 69, 69v
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 106v
div.ab: The lower than usual figure of ‘iij s. iiij d.’ is due to the fact that no Christmas commons was kept this year, presumably because of plague.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 115v
div.ab: The lower than usual figure of ‘iij s. iiij d.’ is due to the fact that Christmas commons were dissolved from 14 November to 13 January, presumably because of plague.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 78
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 135v
div.ab: The records provide no explanation as to why the musicians did not receive a further amount at Candlemas to make up the usual annual wage of 40s.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 147
div.ab: The accounts on this folio are for a two-year period covering 1524–5 and 1525–6 (16 and 17 Henry VIII). The governors’ order referenced here (‘mandatum Gubernatorum,’ l.26) has not been found in the Black Books.

div.head: STC: 12723a Part Henry VIII, ff 154v-5
div.ab: This passage is cited nearly verbatim by Raphael Holinshed, Chronicles of England, vol 3 (London, 1587; STC : 13569), 894. An external reference to the ‘plaie at Grayes inne’ occurs in a letter from Archbishop William Warham to his chaplain Henry Gold, 6 February 1526/7 (see Appendix 4). The lost play, which has been called ‘Lord Governance and Lady Public Weal,’ has been the subject of much speculation (see Appendix 6.2). Apart from a play proposed by William Baldwin in or about 1555–6 (see p 80), it is the only Inns of Court play prior to Gorboduc (1561–2) whose subject is known.

div.head: STC 11125 pp 1013-14
div.ab: Foxe’s narrative continues with the story of Simon Fish’s A Supplicacyon for the Beggers (Antwerp?, 1529; STC: 10883). The Simon Fish affair is not recorded in earlier editions (STC: 11222–4). The letter of Archbishop William Warham (see preceding endnote) confirms the date of 1526–7.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a3 (Black Book 3) f 162v
div.ab: The gist of these entries is that the musicians received their payment this year not as a wage but as a gift, since it was decided not to keep ‘solempne Crystemas’ because of the ‘grette darth’ (f 161).

div.head: Wing: D2488 p 285 col 1
div.ab: Surviving Gray’s Inn Pension Books date from 1568–9; apparently Dugdale had access to an earlier book, now lost.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 78
div.ab:
Uncertainty over the date of this entry derives from the MS heading ‘die veneris videlicet 5 Februarij’: as 4 February 1529/30 was a Friday, either the day of the week should be Saturday or the day of the month should be the 4th. The next council (f 186v) is said to be on Sunday, 14 February, but this is similarly problematic: the council met either on Sunday the 13th or Monday the 14th. Oddly all the dates and days of the week mentioned here coincide with those for the previous year, 1528–9, but this entry occurs in series in the entries for the twenty-first year of the reign of Henry VIII (22 April 1529–21 April 1530), and is explicitly dated as such. Whatever the date of the entry, the disguising and banquet were presumably held on Candlemas, 2 February, the preceding Wednesday.
This disguising is not listed in C.E. McGee and John C. Meagher, ‘Preliminary Checklist of Tudor and Stuart Entertainments: 1485–1558,’ Research Opportunities in Renaissance Drama 25 (1982), 31–114.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) ff 10, 18v
div.ab: Lincoln’s Inn, along with the Inner and Middle Temples, agreed not to keep a solemn Christmas this year for reasons not stated in the records. Thomas Rushton, who had been appointed (f 8) to serve as marshal before the solemn Christmas was cancelled, was reappointed to the office for the following year (f 20) at his request (f 10).

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 21
div.ab: Regulations for the Christmas commons were laid down on 25 November 1527 (LI Arch: A1a3, Black Book 3, f 162), establishing allowances of 10s for a boar and 10s for a cart-load of coals.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 45v
div.ab: On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: Wing: W1046 p 546
div.ab: This antiquarian publication is cited at length by D.S. Bland, ‘Henry VIII’s Royal Commission on the Inns of Court,’ Journal of the Society of Public Teachers of Law, ns, 10 (1969), 178–94. As the document survives in an antiquarian publication only, dated 1663, it has not been possible to assign a more precise date. The commissioners were Nicholas Bacon, Thomas Denton, and Robert Carey. The early date sorts with Bacon’s career, which is well known (see ODNB), while the closing date is established by the death of Henry VIII.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 103
div.ab: Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 59
div.ab: The list of Christmas officers for 1534–5 also appears in rough on f 58.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 75
div.ab: The solemn Christmas was cancelled this year due to plague (f 74v).

div.head: LI Arcch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 100
div.ab: The solemn Christmas was cancelled this year due to plague (f 100).

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 114
div.ab: The date of this parliament is given as 14 November in Inderwick (p 122); however, this has been cancelled in the MS and corrected to 16 November (f 114).

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 119
div.ab: No treasurer’s accounts survive for this year.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 133
div.ab: No treasurer’s accounts survive for this year.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 140
div.ab: No treasurer’s accounts survive for this year.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 48v
div.ab: As ff 34–54 of the acts of parliament are misbound, foliation breaks here with seriatim order. There is no list of appointments for this year. Folio damaged by post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch PAR/1/1 f 51
div.ab: As ff 34–54 of the acts of parliament are misbound, foliation breaks here with seriatim order.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) ff 181-1v
div.ab: The ‘Iustes & Turney on Shroue mondaye & Tuysdaye’ celebrated the coronation of Edward VI, which occurred on Sunday, 20 February 1546/7. The two days following, 21 and 22 February, were Shrove Monday and Tuesday. On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 230
div.ab: This entry reveals that the minstrel John Brayne (or ‘drayne’) had been living in a room in the Inn and that he moved either out of the Inn or into a different room in this year.

div.head: Wing: D2488 p 285 col 1
div.ab: Surviving Gray’s Inn Pension Books date from 1568–9; apparently Dugdale had access to an earlier book, now lost.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 129
div.ab: Folio damaged by post-World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 132
div.ab: Folio damaged by post-World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 135v
div.ab: This entry occurs first on f 135 among unformatted entries, is there cancelled, and has been rewritten here in the traditional layout.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 139
div.ab: No Inner Temple appointments to the office of master of the revels are recorded for this or subse- quent years. Christmas officers hereafter are limited to marshals, stewards, and butlers. Compare to Middle Temple, where such records cease at the end of the reign of Mary.

div.head: Folger Shakespeare Library: MS L.b.298 f [1]
div.ab: This letter is photographically reproduced, transcribed, and partly annotated in Jean F. Preston and Laetitia Yeandle, English Handwriting 1400–1650: An Introductory Manual (Binghamton, NY, 1992), 42–3.

div.head: MT Arch: MT.1/MPA/No. 3 f 28v
div.ab: No Middle Temple appointments to Christmas offices are recorded after this year (1558–9). Compare to Inner Temple where such records cease after 1554–5.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a4 (Black Book 4) f 347v
div.ab: The minstrel’s ‘Rewarde’ was a gift in addition to Robert Jugleger’s regular salary. The reason for the gift is explained in the similar entry for 1560–1 (see p 84).

div.head: IT Arch: ADM/1/1 p 26
div.ab: Arthur Brooke’s sponsors, Thomas Sackville and Thomas Norton, are the authors of Gorboduc, also performed this year. For more on Brooke’s literary activities this year, see Appendix 6.1, Masque of Beauty and Desire.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) ff 2v, 3
div.ab: Whether the name ‘Roberto Harper’ should be understood as ‘Robert Harper’ or ‘Robert (Jugleger,) harper’ is uncertain. Of the two editors Professor Nelson prefers the second option, while Professor Elliott preferred the first, arguing in a handwritten note, ‘Since this was Robert Jugliger’s last year of service (in subsequent years he drew an allowance for his “poverty and feebleness”), it seems likely that “Roberto Harper” was hired as a temporary assistant to a much older man.’

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) ff 4, 17
div.ab: The musicians were compensated for their lost wages in the following year. The accounts recorded in 1563–4 were for two years, 1562–3 and 1563–4 (f 15v).

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) ff 10, 18
div.ab: The accounts recorded in 1563–4 were for two years, 1562–3 and 1563–4 (f 15v).

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) ff 21, 37-7v
div.ab:
Richard Edwards was admitted to Lincoln’s Inn (as ‘Ricardus Edwardes londoniensis’) on 25 November 1564, sponsored by William Roper and George Fisher (f 27v). Could this ‘plee’ have been Richard Edwards’ Damon and Pithias? See Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, p 34.
The entry on f 21 (p 87, ll.26–7) reveals that of the 20s allocated to the children on ff 37–7v (p 88, l.1), half was intended for the usher of the queen’s chapel.

div.head: AGS: Estado, Legajo 818, 1 1 ff[1-1v]
div.ab: ‘Iuno y Diana’ (l.19) apparently refers to a lost play on Juno, Diana, and Pallas Athena by the gentlemen of Gray’s Inn, at Whitehall, 4–6 March 1564/5: see Appendix 6.2.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 46v
div.ab: The title of the play (‘vno ludo,’ ll.13–14) is unknown. In September of the same year Edwards’ lost ‘Palamon and Arcite’ was performed before the queen in Oxford, acted by university students: see REED: Oxford, vol 1, pp 138–43.

div.head: AGS: Estado, Legajo 819, 105 f [1]
div.ab: The eighth earl of Sussex (‘Susex,’ l.30) was Thomas Radcliffe (1526/7–83). The wedding of his sister Frances to Thomas Mildmay was the occasion of Thomas Pounde’s oration: see Appendix 6.1 (p 741). The tenth earl of Ormond (‘Hormut,’ l.34) was Thomas Butler (1531–1614). On the general subject of jousts and tournaments, see p 916, endnote to LI Arch: A1a1 f 62v.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 71v
div.ab: Edward Manners, fifth earl of Rutland (l.36), was offered a new chamber in Lincoln’s Inn on 2 June 1567 at a low price ‘for the good will that he and his ancestors have shown to the House’ (f 56v). Manners was then seventeen years old and a ward of the queen.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 88v
div.ab: John Dutton (1.27) is almost certainly the actor (here in the capacity of a musician), brother of Laurence Dutton, as discussed by Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, p 314. It may be noted, however, that a gentleman of the same name was admitted to Lincoln’s Inn in 1557, and another in 1564. The reference to ‘Hickes’ (l.30) is noted by Lynn Hulse, ‘Sir Michael Hickes (1543–1612): A Study in Musical Patronage,’ Music and Letters 66 (1985), 220–1; in the full article (pp 220–7), Hulse documents Hickes’ interest in music.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 124v
div.ab: Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, p 92, reasonably suggests that ‘Roche’ (l.38) is an error for ‘Riche,’ as Lord Roche of Fermoy was Irish and unlikely to have had players in London. Robert Rich, second Baron Rich (c 1537–80/1), had a company of players who performed at court on 5 February 1569/70, three days after the date of this entry. The players may therefore have been actors rather than musicians, or perhaps both.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 204v
div.ab: The marginal note is a cross-reference to a payment made to musicians on 27 January 1582/3 (see p 106).

div.head: GI Arch: PEN/1/1 ff 144-4v
div.ab: Only the eighth item cited here (p 103, ll.1–3), and by implication the seventh, are certainly associated with a play.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5 f 314
div.ab: Richard Farrant (‘magistro fferand,’ l.34) was the deputy master of the children of the Chapel, 1576–80. The ‘commedia’ is not otherwise known; for the company’s repertory, see Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, pp 35–6.

div.head: IT Arch: PAR/1/1 f 220v
div.ab: Folio damaged in post–World War II fire; the date is supplied from Inderwick. The cross-reference is to the 1577–8 entry (p 101).

div.head: GI Arch: PEN/1/1 ff 177v, 184
div.ab:
A connection between the four song-books and Gray’s Inn revels is suggested by a similar reference in the Gray’s Inn Ledger Books 1584–5 (p 108, l.3). After this year accounts occur not in the Pension Book but in the Ledger Book.
Scholars consulted on these song-books (Steven W. May and musicologists David Fallows and John Milsom) agree that there is no obvious candidate for an English secular song-book of this date available in multiple (including printed) copies, but they note the possibility of foreign chansons or madrigals, arrangements of metrical psalms, contemporary five-part music, second-hand prints or manuscripts, bespoke manuscripts, or music written into books printed as blank scores (see STC : 7567.5).

div.head: GI Arch: FIN/1/1 f 3v
div.ab: For another reference to books for singing, see preceding note.

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 386v
div.ab:
The money recorded in the musicians’ roll (ll.22–3) was collected by the steward from the members of the society and given to the butler to pay to the consort employed at All Saints and Candlemas. Excess money was returned to the treasurer, as recorded here. Since the butler’s expenses are never itemized in the extant treasurers’ accounts, these payments are only visible in years when there was a surplus returned to the treasurer by the steward. Beginning in 1592–3, however, the lack of a surplus was also reported in years when the excess money was used to make up deficits in other expenses of commons. The rolls did not cover Christmas, when the musicians were paid by the Christmas steward (originally a fellow, later one of the butlers) out of a lump sum allotted for ‘the expenses of the fellows at Christmas commons,’ an entry that always follows immediately after the entry for ‘Stipendia Musicorum’ in the accounts. See, for example, LI Arch: A1a6, Black Book 6, f 607v (1615–16).
The ‘ayed Rowle’ (that is, ‘aid roll,’ l.24) probably recorded loans for new building work. See LI Arch: A1a5, Black Book 5, f 386v.

div.head: MT Arch: MT.1/MPA/No. 3 f 171v
div.ab: For an entry concerning the lord of Candlemas night, which follows the passage cited here, see p 118 and endnote.

div.head: GI Arch: PEN/1/1 f 192
div.ab: The ‘comedy or shew’ (p 110, l.39) was presumably the lost Roman comedy called, for want of a formal title, ‘Sylla Dictator’: see Appendix 6.2. As many as three plays may have been performed over the year, as set out in Appendix 8.

div.head: GI Arch: FIN/1/1 ff 17, 23v
div.ab:
Axton, The Queen’s Two Bodies (London, 1977), 79, refers to the events of this year as ‘the first Gesta Grayorum revels.’
The ‘play in michelmas terme’ was evidently the lost Roman comedy (see also pp 112–13).

div.head: BL: Lansdowne MS 55 ff [1], [2v]
div.ab: The personal names in this list are for the most part bracketed by colons, here omitted. William ‘Hatclyff ’ (p 112, l.33) is proposed by Leslie Hotson, Mr W.H. (London and New York, 1964), 109, as the ‘Mr W.H.’ of Shakespeare’s Sonnets.

div.head: BL: Additional MS 4125 single sheet
div.ab: This poem is printed and discussed by Janet Cowen and Joanna Udall, ‘The Critical Misfortunes of Arthur?’ Notes and Queries 228 (1983), 402 – 5. According to the authors (p 405), the poem ‘confirms the suspicions aroused by the documentation in the printed octavo that some bad feeling had arisen in connection with the play.’

div.head: LI Arch: A1a5 (Black Book 5) f 445
div.ab: No musicians’ roll is recorded this year because the steward, Ralph Metcallffe, left his position and failed to finish his accounts (f 443). But the money was no doubt collected by the musicians, as the new steward, Abraham Ripley, continued the custom the following year.

div.head: GI Arch: PEN/1/1 f 198v
div.ab: The musicians recovered only £7 of the £8 plus 26s 8d that they normally received for their activities over Christmas.
